Checked with OpenBLAS author, Windows binary distribution _DOES_ support multi-threading. I also tried on my own machine, setting OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS to 16 boosts the CPU utilization to 100% on my 16-core machine.

I think it depends on how the cifar example uses the library. If it does not use matrix multiplication much, you will not see much speedup when using multiple threads. I think for Cifar, most of the time should be spent on the convolution layers? Then it comes to how convolution is implemented on CPU. Can @antinucleon shed light on this?

@tqchen ,I use the demo of the cifar-100.ipynb, for the classfication task of 146 classes. I don't modify any configuration except input data(batch size=32 for memory limitation). The accracy keeps falling down from 90% to 54% and begin to shock weakly around 55%. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5026576/11839685/b33b9f8e-a42a-11e5-8c37-b50dc97513d0.png)

Moreover, when i set another net (34layers ResNet of MSRA), the same problem is happened, the data is ilsvrc2012 and the accuracy decrease from 19% to 1% and keeps decrease  up to now.I try many configuration and the result is the same. The current params are as follows:
model_args={}
model_args['clip_gradient']=5
model_args['lr_scheduler']=mx.lr_scheduler.FactorScheduler(step=50000,factor=0.5)
model = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=mx.gpu(), symbol=softmax, num_epoch=num_epoch,
learning_rate=0.01, momentum=0.9, wd=0.0001,initializer= mx.init.Xavier(rnd_type='gaussian',factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34),arg_params=model_args)
if you use a smaller batch size, it is likely you need to re-tune your parameter with a smaller learning rate
Could due to not frequent flush and force kill instead of normal exit of the program
so the content that has not yet been flushed will not occur on the log

In this case, seems most scores are relatively small, which could cause such difference. 
The difference could amplify with nets that comes with batch normalization (which is in the inception-bn we used). I am not sure if this is the exact cause of the problem though. 

If we can get some comparison on, say exact same model on other toolkits, we could get a better sense on what was going on
close this PR till @tornadomeet 's update
I find where is wrong,thank you!
it's possible, the log is transferred back via ssh in default, it may be delayed if the network is quite busy. you probably can reconfigure `logging` in python to write the log into disk

@piiswrong still the same error, my build dir now is:

![2015-12-17 6 18 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5208653/11855582/15a3ceca-a486-11e5-9f91-6bcd6e54a72f.png)

Yes, I think we can do that. For BatchNorm specificially. Note that gradient of BN need to be changed, as the formula becomes

```
out = (in - moving_mean)/ moving_var * beta + gamma
```

and moving mean and `moving_var`  are constant now.

Loop in @mavenlin and @antinucleon 

Please propose a proper backprop rule and we can check and then do a PR

I would propose having the `is_train` flag saved inside the graph executor as a member variable of GraphExecutor when forward is called (and partialForward) and that saved value used / passed into RunOps on the backward pass.

I am normally hesitant of this hidden data passing, but my understanding of how mxnet deals with data needed for ops is that one needs to always call a forward pass before calling a backward pass to calculate needed data. Thus having a possible mismatch between the two (one to forward and one to backward) could cause user error. Another option would be to shove this state up to the front end language and keep everything very explicit on the cpp side. I am not sure which is preferable.

With this in place, ops that use the is_train flag on the forward pass would be changed to correctly use this flag.
These currently just include:
- [ ] batchnorm
- [ ] dropout
- [ ] others?

How does this sound?

Edit: Wait did you mean like update rule / formula?
Isn't that something like:

`in_grad = slope / sqrt(var+eps) * out_grad`
`slope = in_data / sqrt(var + eps) * out_grad`
`gamma = out_grad`

After some debugging with @zhubuntu, we found that Windows 7 cannot correctly execute the problem, while Windows 8.1 and Windows 10 work fine. If you are having the same issue, try @freepjf 's approach, or upgrade your OS.

You may use

``` python
mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data = ..., label = ..., name = ...)
```

There is little tutorial about this. I'm not sure the caffe one can be found here. In addition, the name of `LogisticRegressionOutput` is hard to understand, I don't know what function it actually does.
This is not yet supported in current initializer. You can however, implement your own initializer to support initializing by the name of the weight
close for inactive status, please feel free to reopen
@hehaodele  you can create initializer by name of the weights, see also https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/902

To get grad of intermediate nodes was not possible in the currently interface because such request is not yet passed in. mainly because some of them are optimized out. There is one hack that we can do to get the gradient, which is by adding another variable to the requested feature map.

``` python
fmap = mx.Convolution(data, num_hidden=10, ..)
dummy = mx.Variable('fmap1')
fmap = fmap + fmap1
```

Then we can pass 0 into dummy in forward and get gradient wrt that feature map in backward

Just tried commit 6977ac7a44414c58e09211f221076e583c252be3, it worked fine.

I agree with that.
I think it will be better if MXNET separated the output operator apart from loss operator.

There's no categorical entropy loss for MXNET.
Considering it's just a kind of sum of log operator,  it should be easy to implement it.
However, the softmax output operater mix loss and output together, and becomes an objective layer.
That means the backward of softmax-outpus operator is not the general meaning of softmax.

The reason to mix softmax and softmax-loss is it's more efficient, I guess?

The major reason for not posing Softmax as an activation, is that it is kinda of special and do not fit into the template of normal operators. We need to add:
- add  mshadow support for general softmax gradient
- if you think we should place this on activation, let us open a issue to vote on this.

For now, can we isolate the change to the softmaxTransform out and merge other changes?
if we do per batch, we will need something like a running average
Conceptually I'm OK with either way. But an independent softmax involves a lot of code duplication
For what use case? If your metric varies violently between batch it's usually a sign of bad things happening. It should be exposed

The mean image is automatically created if the specified path does not exist

If you are working with your custom DataIter, Try 

``` Python

def load_mean(fname, data_iter, label_mean=False):
    if not fname.endswith('.npz'):
        fname += '.npz'
    if os.path.isfile(fname):
        return np.load(fname)
    else:
        print('Mean file %s not found. Computing mean...'%fname)
        data_iter.reset()
        mean_list = [np.zeros(shape[1:], dtype=np.float64) for name, shape in data_iter.provide_data]
        name_list = [name for name, shape in data_iter.provide_data]
        if label_mean:
            mean_list += [np.zeros(shape[1:], dtype=np.float64) for name, shape in data_iter.provide_label]
            name_list += [name for name, shape in data_iter.provide_label]
        count = 0
        for batch in data_iter:
            arr_list = batch.data
            if label_mean:
                arr_list += batch.label
            for arr, mean in zip(arr_list, mean_list):
                arr = arr.asnumpy()
                mean += arr[:arr.shape[0]-batch.pad].sum(axis=0)
            inc = batch.data[0].shape[0]-batch.pad
            count += inc
            if count/1000 > (count-inc)/1000:
                print('processed %d'%count)
        data_iter.reset()
        mean_list = [(mean/count).astype(np.float32) for mean in mean_list]
        mean_dict = dict(zip(name_list, mean_list))
        np.savez(fname, **mean_dict)
        return mean_dict
```

This is a script I have been using but haven't got the time to commit it to the main repo. First set mean to zero, then call this with your data_iter, and set mean to the returned value

The symbolic computation currently do not support runtime input resizing. This can be added by two ways
- Support runtime reshaping of the graph nodes.
- Support tvia a purely imperative API
